## A Day in the Life with Diabetes: How Canadians Can Thrive

Living with diabetes can present daily challenges, but it doesn't have to stop you from enjoying a fulfilling life. By following a consistent routine, managing your diet, and incorporating the right supplements, you can better control your blood sugar levels and improve your overall health. Here's a day in the life of a Canadian thriving with diabetes:

### Morning (7:00 am - 10:00 am)

Your morning routine plays a crucial role in setting the tone for the rest of the day. Start by waking up at the same time each day to help regulate your body's internal clock, making it easier to manage your blood sugar levels.

After waking, check your blood sugar levels using a glucometer. Record the results in a journal or app to monitor trends and share with your healthcare provider. Next, take any prescribed medications or insulin, and enjoy a balanced breakfast consisting of fiber-rich whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats.

### Midday (10:00 am - 1:00 pm)

Staying active is essential for managing diabetes. Engage in low-impact activities such as walking, swimming, or yoga for at least 30 minutes per day. Aim to break up periods of sitting with short, brisk walks to help lower blood sugar levels.

Before lunch, test your blood sugar again to ensure it's within a healthy range. Then, enjoy a nutritious meal filled with non-starchy vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains. Limit processed foods and added sugars, which can cause spikes in blood sugar levels.

### Afternoon (1:00 pm - 5:00 pm)

After lunch, manage stress through relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, or mindfulness exercises. High stress levels can negatively impact blood sugar management, so incorporating stress-reducing activities into your daily routine can significantly improve your overall health.

Stay hydrated throughout the day, sipping on water or herbal tea to maintain optimal blood sugar levels and prevent dehydration.

### Evening (5:00 pm - 8:00 pm)

Prepare a balanced dinner with lean proteins, non-starchy vegetables, and whole grains. Be mindful of portion sizes and avoid overeating, as larger meals can lead to increased blood sugar levels.

After dinner, engage in a hobby or activity that brings you joy. Social connections and mental well-being are essential for managing diabetes, so make time for relationships and self-care.

### Night (8:00 pm - 11:00 pm)

Wind down for the day by powering off electronic devices and creating a calming environment in your bedroom. Aim to get 7-8 hours of sleep each night to help regulate your body's metabolic processes and maintain healthy blood sugar levels.

Before bed, test your blood sugar levels one last time to ensure they're within a healthy range.
